@thumbtack/tp-ui-core-function.readme:
# `tp-ui-core-function`

## Import in your Sass file

To use Thumbprint UI functions add the following import statement at the top of your Sass file.

```scss
@import '@thumbtack/tp-ui-core-function/_index';
```

## Spacer Function Usage

When using margin or padding vales in your Sass use the `tp-spacer(N)` function where `N` is an increment of `0.5`. Our base spacer unit is `8px`.

```scss
.my-component {
    margin-bottom: tp-spacer(2); // equivalent to 16px
    padding: 0 tp-spacer(2.5); // equivalent to 20px
}
```

This function will provide more consistent spacing and should we change our default grid value in the future to, say `10px`, we'll be able to apply this globally.

## HTML classes

For spacing classes to use in your HTML see [tp-ui-utility-margin](https://thumbprint.thumbtack.com/docs/tp-ui-utility-margin) and [tp-ui-utility-padding](https://thumbprint.thumbtack.com/docs/tp-ui-utility-padding)

# `tp-ui-core-reset`

Sets properties like margin, padding, font-weight and and list-styles to a common minimum.

```
h1,
h2,
h3,
h4,
h5,
h6,
... {
    margin: 0;
    padding: 0;
}

```

# `tp-ui-core-variable` ## Import in your Sass file To use Thumbprint UI variables add the following import statement at the top of your Sass file. ```scss @import '@thumbtack/tp-ui-core-variable/_index'; ``` ## Colors ### Link Colors To change anchor link colors first see if a class already exists in [Anchor](/docs/docs/tp-ui-element-a/). If you have a custom case use the variable as needed. Remember to consider hover and active states. #### Example ``` .my-anchor-class { color: $tp-color__link__bad-news; } ``` | Sass Variable | | | Notes |---|---|---| |`$tp-color__link__base`|
| `#3f93f3`| Anchor tag default color | |`$tp-color__link__light`|
| `#70acf1`| | |`$tp-color__link__faint`|
| `#94beee`| | |`$tp-color__link__bad-news`|
| `#ff4847`| Errors and warnings | |`$tp-color__link__white`|
| `#fff` | On dark backgrounds, consider using underline | ### Text Colors To change the color of text use the variables from this category. Note that a class may already exist in the [Type](/docs/tp-ui-utility-type/) utility. #### Example ``` .my-element { color: $tp-color__text__muted; } ``` | Sass Variable | | | Notes |---|---|---| |`$tp-color__text__base`|

See [Type](docs/tp-ui-element-type/) all class options and size examples. A button communicates what action will occur when the user touches it. It consists of text, an icon, or both. Usually used wrapped with `tp-button-row` to provide correct spacing between buttons.

## Button Full

## Button with Icon
## Transprent Button with Icon

Inside a grid.
## Button with Responsive Icon This content of the button will wrap according to the grid classes, in this case the icon and text will convert to stacked below the 'small' breakpoint. Options are: - tp-button-icon--stack--small - tp-button-icon--stack--medium - tp-button-icon--stack--large
## Button styled as Link This removes browser styles defaults from a button so that it can be styled like an anchor. Use with any [Anchor](docs/tp-ui-element-a/) classes.
This is an example of a that’s styled like a link.

## Best practices - Buttons should be less than 3 words, title cased.

@thumbtack/tp-ui-element-a.readme:
# `tp-ui-element-a` Links use the `$tp-color__link__base`. You can also apply a `.tp-link--` class with a variation below for different link styles.
Links can be link color by default.
Links can be a dark color.
Links can be muted if needed.
Links can convey a dangerous action.
Links can have an underline when needed.
Links can be reversed in color and underlined.
Text can have link color when not a HTML anchor.
Links can be disabled if need be.
## Inherit colors inside anchors In this example an entire block of content is inside a link. Ordinarily all the text would be colored with the default blue color. By using `tp-link--inherit` all text blocks inherit their original colors. Note: In this example you'll likely want to add `display: block;` so you can add background color, border, padding, etc.

This is a heading

And this is some text, both should gray even though we're inside an anchor
and this is the brand color, inside the anchor

# `tp-ui-element-button` ## Button Note: these examples require the [tp-ui-element-button](/docs/tp-ui-layout-button-row) package. A button communicates what action will occur when the user touches it. It consists of text, an icon, or both. Usually used wrapped with `tp-button-row` to provide correct spacing between buttons.
Anchors as buttons.
Click Me Click Me Click Me Click Me
## Wider Button Spacing Variation
## Button Right
## Button Center
## Button Left/Right Alignment
## Button Small
## Button Large
## Button Narrow For use in tight spaces, for example a row of navigation icons.
## Button Flush Removes left and right padding for buttons that need to align with the left or right boundry.
## Button Full
## Button Bleed This button should fill the browser width with no whitespace on either side.
## Button with Icon
## Transprent Button with Icon
## Button with Icon Stacked
Inside a grid.
## Button with Responsive Icon This content of the button will wrap according to the grid classes, in this case the icon and text will convert to stacked below the 'small' breakpoint. Options are: - tp-button-icon--stack--small - tp-button-icon--stack--medium - tp-button-icon--stack--large
## Button styled as Link This removes browser styles defaults from a button so that it can be styled like an anchor. Use with any [Anchor](docs/tp-ui-element-a/) classes.
This is an example of a that’s styled like a link.
## Button Disabled
## Disabled anchors as buttons Use classes instead of `disabled` attribute.
Click Me Click Me Click Me Click Me
## Best practices - Buttons should be less than 3 words, title cased.

@thumbtack/tp-ui-element-type.readme:
# `tp-ui-element-type` ## Body text Classes to define body text for sentences and paragraphs.
20px (mobile) / 24px is the text size that forms sentences and can run as long as it needs to to fill up the space. It should still look good.
20px is the text size that forms sentences and can run as long as it needs to to fill up the space. It should still look good.
16px is the text size that forms sentences and can run as long as it needs to to fill up the space. It should still look good.
14px is the text size that forms sentences and can run as long as it needs to to fill up the space. It should still look good.
12px is the text size that forms sentences and can run as long as it needs to to fill up the space. It should still look good.
## Headings Headings — h1 through h6 — require classes for sizing. This means developers make two important choices: - What is the most appropriate heading for SEO and semantics? - What size should it be? Marketing sites may want to use larger sizes, applications small sizes. This prevents developers from using a heading level only because it happens to be the size they want.

32px (mobile) / 48px is our heading size and it too may run long and wrap to a second line but we should be ready for that.

30px (mobile) / 40px is our heading size and it too may run long and wrap to a second line but we should be ready for that.

24px (mobile) / 32px is our heading size and it too may run long and wrap to a second line but we should be ready for that.

20px (mobile) / 24px is our heading size and it too may run long and wrap to a second line but we should be ready for that.

16px (mobile) / 20px is our heading size and it too may run long and wrap to a second line but we should be ready for that.

14px (mobile) / 16px is our heading size and it too may run long and wrap to a second line but we should be ready for that.

### Removed
- [Major] Remove `text-align` variations in `tp-grid--center` and `tp-grid--end`. These are unintuitive defaults and any text alignment be added by the component. Existing grids that rely on the `text-align` defaults, like the heading/subheadings on `/jobs` will need to add `text-align: center` (Fixes #144)
- [Major] Remove top and bottom negative margin on `tp-grid` and top and bottom padding on `tp-col` that offset the outer margin. This was causing spacing issues with content immediately below the grid. Exiting grids that rely on the spacing will need to be updated. (Fixes #148)

@thumbtack/tp-ui-layout-grid.readme:
# `tp-ui-layout-grid` Grid column widths assume a "mobile first" approach. If columns widths need to change based on browser width you can supply additional column widths that apply at breakpoint. Column class options: - `.tp-col` sets required common column styling - `.tp-col--sm-N` applies above the small breakpoint, `N` is a value between 1 and 12 - `.tp-col--md-N` applies above the medium breakpoint, `N` is a value between 1 and 12 - `.tp-col--lg-N` applies above the large breakpoint, `N` is a value between 1 and 12 ## Spacing between columns By default, a gutter of 16px is present between columns. See options below to widen or remove it. There is no added spacing above or below grids or columns. If you need top or bottom spacing, add it to the content inside the columns. In the examples below each `doc-example-box` has `margin-bottom: 16px`. ## Responsive A common example where at "mobile" size the columns are stacked, full-width, and above the small breakpoint are 33% wide.

@thumbtack/tp-ui-layout-wrap.readme:
# `tp-ui-layout-wrap` Note that the wrapper class examples have a red outline for documenation purposes only. ## Wrap A basic wrapper with max-width and left/right padding.
## Wrap Snap This provides a wrapper around content that "snaps" to fixed max-widths depending on the breakpoint. You can put any content in this wrapper.
The layout of the content inside the `wrap-snap` can be adjusted using the provide breakpoint mixins, for example: ``` .my-component { @include tp-respond-above($tp-breakpoint__medium) } ``` ## Wrap Bleed In some cases you'll want the wrapper to be full width with no padding at mobile, that is, below the small breakpoint.

# `tp-ui-utility-sizing` Width helper classes are used to set percentage and fixed widths on elements, commonly for table columns.
Name Hometown Status Animal
Stan Smith Sarasota Single Elephant
Jenny Holtzer Bloomington Married Tiger
## Percentage Widths The class variations express the width as a fraction: the dash separates the numerator and denominator. Note that the extra percision helps in some browsers. Some examples: - `tp-width--1-3` = `width: 33.333% !important;` - `tp-width--1-6` = `width: 16.666% !important;` - `tp-width--2-5` = `width: 40% !important;` Width classes can be expressed with any of the following as the denominator. - 2 - 3 - 4 - 5 - 6 - 8 - 10 - 12

# `tp-ui-utility-type` ## Monospace
Text can be in a monospace font.
## Text Colors
Text can be in base color. This is the color text will get by default and will be used to override text color that is of another color.
Text can be in brand color.
This is something that good.
You should be aware of bad information.
Text can be muted.
Text can white against a dark background.
## Text Weights
This is normal weight, equivalent to font-weight: 400.
This is equivalent to font-weight: 500.
This is equivalent to font-weight: 600.
## Text Styles ### Strikeout
You may want to strike out some text.
### Uppercase
You may want to use uppercase in some cases.
## Breaking text
When you have a lot of text on a single line you sometimes don't want it to wrap or run off the screen.
http://www.thumbtack.com/this/is/a/long/path/that/could/go/and/not/break/the/way/you/want/it/to.html
This text will not wrap. See [#section-dropdown](#section-dropdown) for usage example.
## Text Alignment
I'm on the left.
I'm in the middle!
Whoa, I'm way over on the right.
